paper: Machine Text Detectors are Membership Inference Attacks

differences.summary: Non-standard LRT statistic (uses L(x;M)/L(x;Q) instead of p_M(x)/p_Q(x))
differences.why_impacts_score: Challenges correctness of the central theoretical claim/statistic

evidence.baseline_quote: Theorem 2.3 formalizes Λ(x)=L(x;M)/L(x;Q) and shows it is the likelihood ratio test for MGTD.
evidence.final_quote: Step 1 states Λ_MGT(x)=L(x;M)/L(x;Q), whereas Neyman–Pearson LRT compares p_M(x)/p_Q(x); no equivalence is shown.

differences.summary: Bayes error/advantage bound applied without proof that Λ attains Bayes optimality
differences.why_impacts_score: Undermines the theoretical guarantees tied to the proposed test statistic

evidence.baseline_quote: An advantage bound linking performance to KL divergence is given... Anchoring expected limits adds interpretability.
evidence.final_quote: Step 3 refers to Bayes error... no proof is given that the proposed Λ(x) attains Bayes optimality.

differences.why_impacts_score: Signals conceptual confusion that weakens theoretical soundness

evidence.baseline_quote: Notational inconsistencies around L(x;M) being “loss” versus “sum of log probabilities” appear across §2.2 and §2.3.
evidence.final_quote: Theorem 2.3 mixes conventions for L... and the theorem text says “minimize the likelihood”.

differences.summary: Technical Quality downgraded due to central statistic formulation and MIA rigor
differences.why_impacts_score: Explicit rationale links lower score to flawed LRT and MIA formalization

evidence.baseline_quote: Technical Quality (10): 6 — ... theoretical rigor for MIAs and lack of uncertainty/operating-point reporting limit robustness.
evidence.final_quote: Technical Quality (10): 5 — ... proposed LRT uses L(x;M)/L(x;Q) ... and MIA formalization lacks distributional rigor...

differences.summary: Summary downgrades ‘proves’ to ‘argues’ about optimal test statistic
differences.why_impacts_score: Reflects reduced acceptance of the paper’s claimed proof

evidence.baseline_quote: It proves, under asymptotic assumptions, that both tasks share the same optimal test statistic.
evidence.final_quote: It argues, under asymptotic assumptions, that both tasks share an optimal test statistic.
